response:
The clinical picture is consistent with an acute to subacute hemicord syndrome (Brown-Séquard). In a 41-year-old, inflammatory/demyelinating causes are statistically most likely. Compressive lesions (disc/tumor) must be excluded due to the neurosurgical emergency implications. Infectious and vascular causes remain on the differential.

differential_diagnosis = ["Acute Transverse Myelitis (Demyelinating - MS, NMO, MOG)", "Compressive Myelopathy (Cervical Disc Herniation)", "Intramedullary or Extramedullary Spinal Tumor", "Infectious Myelitis (Varicella Zoster, Lyme, Syphilis, HIV)", "Spinal Cord Infarction", "Neurosarcoidosis"]
